comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: Though officially allied with Germany and Austria-Hungary, Italy entered the war on May 23, 1915 on the side of England, France and Russia. This led to huge, peaceful demonstrations in New York's Italian neighborhoods. The Italian Consulate was at that time at 226 Lafayette St, on Cleveland Place in Little Italy. According to a New York Times account, it was one of the busiest places in New York that week, owing to the fact that it kept track of the 200,000 Italian army and navy reservists in New York. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F30617FA385C1373... select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10B1EF83A5A1773... Both buildings in the picture are still there: maps.google.com/maps?q=226+lafayette+st+nyc&ll=40.722...
